whatIs.title: What Is a Promissory Note?
content: Transfers ownership from seller to buyer
Documents key facts (price, VIN, mileage, “as-is” notice, etc.)
Triggers title & registration at your state DMV
Protects both parties against future tax, lien, or liability disputes
whatIs.footer: Think of it as your proof of ownership and condition on the day the keys change hands.

rows: Personal loan to family or friends
Business owner lending to their own LLC
Shows evidence of debt for title insurers and tax authorities
Equipment or vehicle sold on installments
Lets seller reclaim asset on default

varieties.title: Promissory Note Varieties
items: Simple (Unsecured) – no collateral; relies on borrower’s creditworthiness
Secured – identifies collateral (e.g., car, equipment) lender may seize if unpaid
Demand – payable any time lender calls the balance due
Installment with Balloon – periodic interest payments plus lump-sum principal at the end
Interest-Only – borrower pays interest during term, principal at maturity
Master Note / Line of Credit – revolving balance with maximum credit limit

rows: Captures exact dollars loaned, avoiding future disputes
Dates, frequency, and format (equal payments, balloon, etc.)
Flat dollar or percentage triggers after grace period
Allows or prohibits early payoff without penalty
VIN, serial number, or legal description of asset
Specifies state law and court jurisdiction
Makes the contract enforceable—some states require notarization

stateRules.title: State-Specific Rules & Usury Caps
stateRules.content: Interest-rate ceilings vary widely (e.g., 10% in New York, up to 30% for certain loans in Texas). Our template blocks rates that exceed your state’s civil or criminal usury limit and flags mandatory notary states.

q1.question: Is an e-signed promissory note valid in court?
q1.answer: Yes. Under the U.S. E-SIGN Act, electronic signatures carry the same legal weight as ink signatures.

q2.question: Do I need a witness or notary?
q2.answer: Most states do not require notarization, but it adds enforcement strength—our checkout offers remote notarization.

q3.question: What happens if the borrower defaults?
q3.answer: The default clause accelerates the full balance; lenders may sue, garnish wages, or seize listed collateral, subject to state law.

q4.question: Can I change the terms later?
q4.answer: Use our Promissory Note Amendment add-on to adjust interest rates, payment dates, or principal without drafting a new note.

q5.question: Is interest taxable?
q5.answer: Yes. Lenders must report interest income; borrowers may deduct qualified business-loan interest.
